description: Deep analysis of strategic silences, structural absences, and constitutive exclusions using Derridean deconstruction, Foucauldian archaeology, and Lacanian theory. Reveals the constitutive outsides that make meaning possible, the traces of what was excluded, the supplements that expose original lacks, the epistemic violence that renders certain subjects unspeakable, and the différance that perpetually defers the presence texts claim to possess. Surfaces what discourse cannot say, will not say, and structurally cannot think.
researcher_question: What is structurally absent, strategically silenced, or rendered unspeakable—and how do these absences constitute what is present?

absent_centers.name: string (evocative name like 'The Missing Worker' or 'The Unspoken Colonial Past')
absent_centers.what_is_absent: string (plain language description of what's not there)
absent_centers.how_it_organizes: string (how the discourse arranges itself around this absence)
absent_centers.why_it_must_stay_absent: string (what would collapse if it became present)
absent_centers.is_acknowledged: boolean (does the text know something is missing?)
traces_of_presence: string (residual marks that hint at the absence)

traces.name: string (evocative name like 'The Palimpsest of Slavery')
traces.what_it_traces: string (what absent thing left this mark)
traces.where_it_appears: string (the textual location/form of the trace)
traces.how_to_read_it: string (interpretive key to seeing the trace)

supplements.name: string (evocative name like 'The Footnote That Swallows the Text')
supplements.supplement_logic: string (how addition reveals lack—Derrida's dangerous supplement)
supplements.is_dangerous: boolean (does it threaten what it supplements?)

constitutive_outsides.name: string (evocative name like 'The Excluded Feminine')
constitutive_outsides.what_it_constitutes: string (what identity depends on this exclusion)

discursive_exclusions.name: string (evocative name)
discursive_exclusions.within_which_formation: string (the discursive formation that excludes it)
discursive_exclusions.penalty_for_transgression: string (what happens if someone says it anyway)

strategic_silences.name: string (evocative name like 'The Unmentioned Funding Source')

eloquent_absences.name: string (evocative name like 'The Dog That Didn't Bark')

epistemic_violences.name: string (evocative name like 'The Categorical Erasure of Indigenous Knowledge')
epistemic_violences.violence_type: silencing | appropriation | distortion | erasure | othering | infantilizing

subaltern_positions.name: string (evocative name)
subaltern_positions.who_is_subaltern: string (those who cannot speak within the discourse)
represented_by: string (speakers who claim to speak for them)

the_unsayable.name: string (evocative name like 'The Class War No One Names')
the_unsayable.closest_approach: string (how discourse gets near it without saying it)

the_unthinkable.name: string (evocative name like 'A World Without Private Property')
symptoms_of_unthinkability: string (how we can detect what can't be thought)
the_unthinkable.who_can_think_it: string (those outside the episteme, if anyone)

presence_claims.name: string (evocative name)
presence_claims.what_claims_presence: string (the identity/meaning/truth that claims to be present)
presence_claims.presence_type: self_presence | full_meaning | origin | foundation | natural_kind | essence

binary_hierarchies.what_is_excluded_entirely: string (the third term that cannot exist—Derrida)

differance_operations.name: string (evocative name like 'The Perpetually Deferred Definition of Democracy')
differance_operations.what_presence_is_promised: string (the presence that is always to come)

lacanian_reals.name: string (evocative name like 'The Traumatic Kernel of History')
lacanian_reals.what_resists_symbolization: string (that which cannot enter the symbolic order)
lacanian_reals.objet_petit_a: string (the object-cause of desire that circles this Real)

formation_rules.objects: string (what objects can be spoken of)

statements_enonces.enunciative_function: string (what makes this a statement in Foucault's sense)
what_it_excludes: string (what it makes impossible to say)

spectral_presences.name: string (evocative name like 'The Ghost of Colonialism')
spectral_presences.what_it_demands: string (the ghost's claim on the present)

nodes.type: string (entity type: absent_center | trace | supplement | etc.)
nodes.label: string (short display name, 2-5 words)
nodes.weight: number (0-1, centrality/importance in the absence structure)

clusters.name: string (evocative cluster name like 'The Colonial Silence Complex')
member_ids: string (entity IDs that form this cluster)

key_findings: string (3-5 major discoveries about what's absent)
deconstructive_opportunities: string (where the text is most vulnerable to deconstruction)

extraction.core_question: What is structurally absent, strategically silenced, or rendered unspeakable—and how do these absences constitute what is present?
extraction_steps: STEP 1 - LOCATE THE ABSENT CENTER: Apply Derrida's insight that every structure has a center that is paradoxically absent. Ask: What organizes this discourse without being fully present? What is the 'hole' around which meaning arranges itself? Look for concepts that are constantly referenced but never defined, origins that are presupposed but never shown, foundations that are asserted but never grounded.

STEP 2 - READ FOR TRACES (DERRIDA): The trace is the mark of what was excluded. Read for: lexical traces (words that carry absent meanings), structural traces (forms that imply missing content), tonal traces (affects that suggest suppressed material), symptomatic traces (slips, contradictions, over-emphases that point elsewhere). Ask: What absent thing left this mark?

STEP 3 - IDENTIFY SUPPLEMENTS (DERRIDA): The supplement both adds to and substitutes for an original that was never complete. Find what is presented as 'mere addition' or 'external support'—these reveal the lack they claim to complete. Apply the logic of the 'dangerous supplement': what claims to be outside and secondary is actually inside and essential.

STEP 4 - MAP CONSTITUTIVE OUTSIDES: Every identity requires an outside it is not. Ask: What must be excluded for this concept/position/identity to exist? What is the 'constitutive outside' without which the inside could not cohere? How is the boundary maintained? What threatens to breach it?

STEP 5 - EXCAVATE DISCURSIVE EXCLUSIONS (FOUCAULT): Apply Foucault's archaeology. What are the rules of this discursive formation? What can be said, and crucially, what cannot? Identify the three procedures of exclusion: prohibition (what is forbidden), the division between reason and madness (what is dismissed as irrational), and the will to truth (what is ruled out as false).

STEP 6 - DETECT STRATEGIC SILENCES: Some silences are tactical. Who benefits from what is not said? Look for: conspicuous omissions, euphemisms that replace direct speech, deflections that change the subject, misdirections that point away, naturalizations that make the constructed seem inevitable.

STEP 7 - IDENTIFY ELOQUENT ABSENCES: Some absences 'speak loudly.' Apply the Sherlock Holmes principle: What is the dog that didn't bark? What should be here given the genre, context, or argument, but isn't? What does the absence communicate?

STEP 8 - ANALYZE EPISTEMIC VIOLENCE (SPIVAK): Where does the discourse do violence to other ways of knowing? How are subaltern epistemologies silenced, appropriated, distorted, or erased? Who is rendered unable to speak within the terms of this discourse? Remember Spivak: the subaltern cannot speak not because they are silent but because the structure cannot hear.

STEP 9 - MAP SUBALTERN POSITIONS: Who is structurally positioned as unable to speak? Not silenced individuals but subject positions that the discourse cannot accommodate. Who speaks 'for' them and with what distortions? What would need to change for them to speak?

STEP 10 - ARTICULATE THE UNSAYABLE: What does the discourse structurally prevent from being said? Not just what is forbidden (taboo) but what is literally inarticulable within its terms (the unsayable proper). What are the symptoms of this unsayability—circumlocutions, hesitations, contradictions?

STEP 11 - IDENTIFY THE UNTHINKABLE (FOUCAULT): Go beyond the unsayable to the unthinkable. What lies outside the episteme entirely? What are the 'conditions of impossibility'—what the conditions of possibility necessarily foreclose? This is not what people choose not to think but what cannot be thought within this epistemic configuration.

STEP 12 - DECONSTRUCT PRESENCE CLAIMS (DERRIDA): Where does the text claim presence, self-evidence, origin, foundation, or natural status? Apply deconstruction: show how each presence depends on absence, how each origin is derived, how each foundation is groundless. Locate the 'metaphysics of presence' at work.

STEP 13 - ANALYZE BINARY HIERARCHIES (DERRIDA): Identify the binary oppositions that structure the discourse. Which term is privileged? How does the subordinated term secretly constitute and enable the privileged one? What 'third term' is entirely excluded by the binary? Map strategies for reversal and displacement.

STEP 14 - TRACE DIFFÉRANCE: Where does meaning perpetually defer? Apply Derrida's différance (difference + deferral). Find the chains of substitution where meaning is endlessly postponed. What presence is always promised but never arrives? Why can it never arrive?

STEP 15 - APPROACH THE REAL (LACAN): What resists symbolization entirely? This is not the unsayable (which could theoretically be said) but the Real that cannot enter the symbolic order. Look for: traumatic repetitions, points where discourse breaks down, the 'impossible' that keeps returning. Identify the objet petit a—the object-cause of desire that circles this void.

STEP 16 - DETECT SPECTRAL PRESENCES (DERRIDA): What ghosts haunt this discourse? Apply Derrida's hauntology: what is neither present nor simply absent but spectrally returns? What past exclusions continue to haunt? What demands do these specters make on the present?

STEP 17 - SYNTHESIZE THE ABSENCE STRUCTURE: Map the relationships between absences. How do they form a system? Which absence is most central (organizing the others)? Which is most violent? Which is deepest? What would happen if any of these absences were made present?
extraction.special_instructions: CRITICAL: Absence analysis requires reading against the grain. Do not take the text at its word about what it includes—look for what it must exclude to say what it says. The most important absences are structural, not accidental. Always ask: What must NOT be here for this to be here? Apply the principle of 'constitutive outside'—every identity depends on what it excludes. Remember Derrida's insight: presence is always contaminated by absence, the inside always depends on the outside, the center is always elsewhere. Work from the margins inward.

consolidation_rules: RULE 1: Merge absences that refer to the same structural gap across documents—these are the same absent center appearing in different texts
RULE 2: Distinguish structural absences (necessary for the discourse to function) from contingent absences (could be otherwise)
RULE 3: Link traces to the absences they trace—build the trace→absence relationship
RULE 4: Identify shared constitutive outsides—the same exclusion operating across texts
RULE 5: Connect subaltern positions to the epistemic violence that creates them
RULE 6: Map relationships between discursive formations—shared exclusion rules
RULE 7: Identify counter-discourses that contest the same silences across documents
RULE 8: Build the hierarchy of absences—which is deepest? (unthinkable > unsayable > silenced > omitted)
curation.special_instructions: In consolidation, prioritize structural over contingent absences. The goal is to surface the systematic architecture of exclusion, not catalog every omission. Look for the SAME absence appearing across texts in different guises—this indicates a constitutive rather than accidental exclusion.

id_examples.to: The Trace of Colonial Violence in 'Development' Discourse
Technology as Dangerous Supplement to Human Nature
The Constitutive Exclusion of Emotion from Rationality
The Strategic Silence on Climate Costs
The Epistemic Violence of 'Objective' News Framing
The Position of the Unheard Worker
The Specter of Slavery Haunting Meritocracy

concretization.naming_guidance: Names should be evocative and specific, capturing what is absent and its structural significance. Use 'The [Adjective] [Absence/Silence/Exclusion/Ghost] of [What's Missing]' pattern. Make absences vivid—name what ISN'T there in a way that makes its absence palpable. Avoid vague names like 'Key Absence 1'—instead, 'The Unmentioned Genocide' or 'The Structurally Silenced Victim.'
recommended_table_types: constitutive_outside_matrix (what excludes what to constitute what)
trace_evidence_table (traces and what they trace back to)
recommended_visual_patterns: hauntology_timeline (what ghosts return from which pasts)
subaltern_speech_map (who speaks for whom with what distortions)

executive.constitutive_outside: what we exclude to define ourselves

activist.supplement: what they add to hide what's missing
